newsitem.title: USA: Investment-grade Uruguay still faces risks -- S&P.
newsitem.headline: Investment-grade Uruguay still faces risks -- S&P.

text.p: Despite ratings upgrades last week, Uruguay still faces risks from neighboring countries and needs to find its place within Mercosur, said Lacey Gallagher, director of sovereign ratings at Standard & Poor's.
Last week Moody's Investors Service raised Uruguay's foreign currency debt ceiling to Baa3 from Ba1, and S&P upped its rating of the country's Eurobonds to BBB-minus from BB-plus.
Uruguay has so far benefited little from South American customs agreement Mercosur, Gallagher said in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.

"Investors are hesitant to invest in Uruguay for Mercosur-related reasons," she said. "Uruguay needs to find its niche as a small open economy which exports mainly primary products and services but does have an educated population it could build on."
For now, Uruguay's economy remains somewhat at the mercy of neighbors Argentina and Brazil, Gallagher said.
"They are more prone to financial instability," she said, adding that economic disturbances in either country could reduce demand for Uruguayan exports or spark higher inflation.
After the recent wave of ratings actions, including several upgrades, relative credit standings among Latin American countries now appear stable near term, Gallagher said.
"We think the relative credit standing of the countries is quite appropriate the way it stands," she said.
